text.tool_tip: Click an item below to create new preset or modify an existing one.

text.name: T_W_R_Types
text.tool_tip: Determines what will show up in water reflections.

text.name: T_R_Res
text.tool_tip: Determines the resolution/quality of water reflections. Whenever resolution settings are set to 'Very Good' or above, you must also enable 'Advanced Lighting Model' in tab 'Light'.

check_box.label: Transparent Water
check_box.name: TransparentWater
check_box.tool_tip: Render water as transparent. Disabling renders water as opaque with a simple texture applied.

check_box.label: Enable Advanced Lighting Model
check_box.name: RenderDeferred
check_box.tool_tip: This will enable shadows from the Sun and Moon and in-world light sources. It will also allow you to turn on Depth of Field and other graphic features. Basically you need to turn this on to see most of the 'eye candy' in-world. If you cannot enable this feature or see its effect, first ensure Atmospheric Shaders is enabled in tab 'Env'.

check_box.label: Enable All Local Lights
check_box.name: LocalLights
check_box.tool_tip: This will turn on all in-world lights. If you disable this feature, light from Sun and Moon will still appear. Useful when you wish to eliminate SIM lighting and use only the Sun and Moon light.

check_box.label: Enable Attached Lights (Face Lights)
check_box.tool_tip: This will enable any lights, such as face lights, avatars have attached to them. Useful for turning off facelights when necessary.

text.name: T_Shadow_Types
text.tool_tip: This setting only affects the shadows that are rendered from light sources, the lights will still function normally otherwise. Point light (lights that do not have the projection feature enabled) will always create a sense of shadows, yet they will not cast them upon any surface. It is important to note that regardless of the setting you choose here, textures projected from projection lights will still be enabled.

text.name: T_Shadow_Res
text.tool_tip: Shadow Resolution: This is a VERY important setting. It determines the quality of the shadows. It also is VERY heavy on the computer. It is a good idea to leave this setting as LOW as possible when you are not shooting. When you are shooting, set it to 1.0 while preparing your shot. When you are ready to take your shot, slowly raise the slider bar to the right. You need to be careful of your framerate while you raise this setting. It is helpful to turn on the Statistics Bar (in tab 'Aids' under 'Interface aids') when you do this for the first few times so you can be familiar with the level of shadows that works best with your system. NOTE: Setting this too high or moving it too fast will cause viewer crashes.

text.name: T_Shd_Clarity
text.tool_tip: This is a VERY important setting. It essentially determines how clear the Sun/Moon shadows are drawn overall. This setting should be set first before adjusting the setting below. With the value of 'Shd. Res' above set to 1.0, slide the value for 'Shd. Clarity' until the sharpest possible result is achieved. Please note, the clarity of shadows is directly related to the position of the camera and Sun/Moon. Every time you move either the camera or the Sun/Moon, it is best to adjust this value again. In addition, in order to make adjusting this value easier, it is helpful to set 'Shd. Blur' to 0.0 first.

text.name: T_Blur_Size
text.tool_tip: The higher the number, the softer the shadow edges. Set to '0' for the sharpest shadows possible. This setting is directly related to the one below it as well. It allows you to set the overall possible amount of shadow blur. If set to 4.00, you can use Shadows Soften to adjust the shadow blur independent of the ambient occlusion. PLEASE NOTE: Ambient Occlusion must be enabled for this setting to work.

text.name: T_Shd_Soften
text.tool_tip: Controls the softening effect of Sun/Moon shadows. One simple way to set this value for your specific needs is to first set the 'Shd. Blur' value above to around 3.0. Then the slider here to soften the AO to your liking. Please note, a value of 0.0 will effectively turn off all Sun/Moon shadows. In addition, this has no effect of shadows the caused by projector lights

text.name: T_Blur_Dist
text.tool_tip: This will determine the point at which the shadows will begin to blur relative to the camera. The lower the value the closer the point of shadow blur will begin. PLEASE NOTE: Ambient Oclussion must be enabled for this setting to work.

text.name: T_FOV_Cutoff
text.tool_tip: This determines the FOV cutoff at which the viewer will switch between ortho instead of perspective projection. If you are getting shadows that are 'jaggedy' try adjusting this setting for improvement. Also adjusting the XYZ values for the debug setting RenderShadowSplitExponent can be VERY helpful.

check_box.label: Enable Ambient Occlusion (Depth Perception)
check_box.name: UseSSAO
check_box.tool_tip: Ambient Occlusion adds shading to all objects. It is most effective when the Effect and AO Soften settings below are used. It can add a high level of realism to the image. This is especially true when images are made at resolutions of 2048 pixels or above.

text.name: T_Scale
text.tool_tip: Controls sampling region; larger regions are more accurate. It can be helpful to set these values high and then add a bit of shadow blur to soften their effect.

text.name: T_Max_Scale
text.tool_tip: Controls maximum screen radius from which to sample from, to avoid graphics card cache misses and associated large performance penalty. It can be helpful to set these values high and then add a bit of shadow blur to soften their effect.

text.name: T_Scaling_Factor
text.tool_tip: Scaling factor for the effect (larger is darker). It can be helpful to set these values high and then add a bit of shadow blur to soften their effect.

text.name: T_Effect
text.tool_tip: Controls the overall darkening effect of Ambient Occlusion. The default value of 0.8 produces an almost imperceptible effect. Values of 0.0 and below provide a more realistic result. Please note that the Ambient Occlusion produces a noise like effect and this can be softened using the 'AO Soften' controls below. In addition, the standard mesh avatar can look less than appealing with high Effect values due to the low quality geometry of the avatar. Please Note: The lowest value you can set in the slider is 0, while in the spinner you can enter negative values of up to -10000.

text.name: T_AO_Soften
text.tool_tip: Controls the softening of the Ambient Occlusion effect. One simple way to set this value for your specific needs is to first set the 'Shd. Blur' value above to around 4.0. Then the slider here to soften the AO to your liking. Please note, a value of 0.0 will effectively turn off Ambient Occlusion rendering.

check_box.label: Enable Depth of Field (DoF)
check_box.name: UseDepthofField
check_box.tool_tip: This will enable Depth of Field which will 'determine distance between the nearest and farthest objects in a scene that appear acceptably sharp in an image' (Wikipedia). If you are not using it turn it off and it will speed up your frame rate. If you cannot enable this feature or do not see its effect, please turn on 'Advanced Lighting Model' in tab 'Light'.

check_box.label: Enable DoF when underwater
check_box.tool_tip: Normally, Depth of Field is disabled when underwater, even with the above box checked. This setting will remove that restriction. Note that you may have to manually refocus your camera on desired objects by alt-clicking on them when you're underwater.
check_box.name: UseDoFUnderwater

check_box.label: Depth of Field focus follows pointer
check_box.name: FSFocusPointFollowsPointer
check_box.tool_tip: Depth of Field (DoF) focus will follow your mouse, this behaviour matches that seen when using flycam. Use in conjunction with DoF focus lock

check_box.label: Show the Current FOV of Viewer Screen
check_box.tool_tip: This will show you the vertical field of view for the camera. Within the viewer it is possible to change the lens length just like in real life. The smaller the FOV the longer the camera lens. A 50mm lens has a FOV of 27.0 degrees. To adjust the FOV use the zoom slider bar below. Please see: 'http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angle_of_view' for a table showing the relationship between FOV and Lens Focal Length (mm). TURN IT OFF BEFORE YOU TAKE SNAPSHOTS OR IT WILL BE IN THE PICTURE!
check_box.name: MIC_Show_FOV

text.name: T_Zoom
text.tool_tip: In real world terms this is a Zoom feature. This will change the field of view in your viewer window. It is the same as hitting Ctrl + 0 or Ctrl+8. NOTE: This will not function if you have flycam enabled (3D SpaceNavigator).

text.name: T_FOV
text.tool_tip: Field of View: This tells the viewer what FOV you would like to simulate for the DOF effect. It is best to set this to the current FOV of the viewer.

text.name: T_F_Number
text.tool_tip: In real world terms this is the aperture setting for the lens and the lower the value the shorter the depth of field will be. The same applies to SL.

text.name: T_Focal_Length
text.tool_tip: Focal Length (mm): This tells the viewer what Focal Length/Lens Length to simulate for the DOF effect. Higher numbers produce a narrower depth of field.

text.name: T_Foc_Time
text.tool_tip: Focus Transition Time: This sets the time in seconds it take to the viewer to change focus from one object.

text.name: T_CoC
text.tool_tip: Circle of Confusion: This is a VERY IMPORTANT SETTING. It determines the strength of the blur itself. It does not change the depth of field, it adjusts how much those objects outside of it will be blurry. Also you can access negative values for interesting effects in the spinner text box.

text.name: T_Resolution
text.tool_tip: Resolution: This determines the quality of the DOF Effect. For non-photography uses '.25' is good. For setting up shots '.50' or '.70' is very nice. For shooting quality images '1.00' is best. High values will slow down your FPS! Also you can access negative values for interesting effects in the spinner text box.

text.name: T_Glow_Quality
text.tool_tip: This will determine the quality of the glow effect, higher is better. There is little visual difference between 8 and 10.

text.name: T_Glow_Iterations
text.tool_tip: Number of times to iterate/repeat the glow (higher = wider and smoother and a bit slower).

text.name: T_Glow_Strength
text.tool_tip: Additive strength of glow. Very low values are needed to see this effect. Start low!

text.name: T_Luminance
text.tool_tip: Minimum luminance intensity necessary to consider an object bright enough to automatically glow.

text.name: T_Warmth
text.tool_tip: Amount of warmth extraction to use (versus luminance extraction). 0 = lum, 1.0 = warmth. OFTEN HAS LITTLE OR NO EFFECT!

text.name: T_Glow_Width
text.tool_tip: Glow sample size. Higher = wider and softer glow, but eventually it will become more pixelated.

text.name: T_Alpha
text.tool_tip: Basically how bright the glow is allowed to get.

text.name: T_Draw_Distance
text.tool_tip: This sets the furthest distance the viewer will draw anything. High values will slow your FPS!

text.name: T_Avi_Count
text.tool_tip: Maximum number of other avatars to render in a scene. Very helpful for situations where many avatars are slowing your FPS.

text.name: T_Avi_Detail
text.tool_tip: Sets the render quality of the avatars. Higher is better!

text.name: T_Avi_Physics
text.tool_tip: Controls level of detail of avatar physics (such as chest physics). Higher is better.

text.name: T_Particle_Cnt
text.tool_tip: Sets the maximum number of particles to render.

text.name: T_Terrain_Scale
text.tool_tip: Sets the quality of the default ground (terrain) texture.

text.name: T_Terrain_Quality
text.tool_tip: Sets the quality of terrain. High numbers mean more detailed terrain in the distance.

text.name: T_Object_Detail
text.tool_tip: Controls when lower-detail objects can be used to reduce rendering cost. Higher values cause lag, use with care.

text.name: T_Flexi_Detail
text.tool_tip: Controls level of detail of flexible objects. Higher means more detail.

text.name: T_Tree_Detail
text.tool_tip: Controls level of detail of vegetation. Higher numbers produce greater detail.

text.name: T_Sky_Detail
text.tool_tip: Controls vertex detail on the WindLight sky. Lower numbers will give better performance and less than lovely skies.

check_box.label: Enable Draw Distance
check_box.name: UseFarClip
check_box.tool_tip: Enable Draw Distance, if you disable this feature the Viewer will render past your set draw distance.

check_box.label: Dynamically adjust level of detail
check_box.name: RednerLod1
check_box.tool_tip: This enables the feature that allows the viewer to dynamically adjust the level of detail in scene as you move further away from objects. It helps improve performance, it also can reduce the quality of the objects in the scene.

check_box.label: Render only Objects visible to the Camera
check_box.tool_tip: This allows the viewer only to process/draw those objects that are within the camera field of view and not hidden behind anything else. Usually this is a performance booster. Sometimes it can actually reduce performance especially when the scene/sim has few objects. Toggle to see if it helps or not!
check_box.name: UssOcclusion1

check_box.label: Anisotropic Filtering (texture crispness)
check_box.tool_tip: This enables higher texture crispness.
check_box.name: Anisotropic

check_box.label: Render Particles Attached to other Avatars
check_box.tool_tip: Enables the viewer to render any and all particles attached to/coming from other avatars.
check_box.name: Render Attached Particle

text.name: T_Anti-aliasing
text.tool_tip: Determines how sharp and smooth the edges of objects will be. On top level graphics cards, higher values have virtually NO performance impact. On lower graphics cards, higher values can slow performance.

text.name: T_Texture_Bumpiness
text.tool_tip: Controls the strength and resolution of normal and bump maps.

text.name: T_Quick_Stats
text.tool_tip: Here you can find some very useful stats for gauging system performance. Expand/Collapse the items below by clicking their labels.

stat_bar.name: fps
stat_bar.label: Frames Per Second
stat_bar.tool_tip: FPS: The number of times per second your computer is redrawing (or refreshing) what's on the screen. Higher numbers are better. A framerate between 12 to 15 is common for animations, 24 is the standard for motion pictures, and 25 (PAL)/30 (NTSC) frames per second (FPS) is the rate for broadcast television.

stat_bar.name: bandwidth
stat_bar.label: Bandwidth
stat_bar.tool_tip: Bandwidth: How much data is being transferred between your computer and the Virtual World. This number varies wildly depending on what bandwidth settings you've used, where you are inworld, what's going on, and whether you're still loading some things (objects/textures/etc) that are in your field of view. If bandwidth is 0 Kbps, something may be wrong (you may be partially disconnected).

stat_bar.name: ktrisframe
stat_bar.label: KTris Drawn per Frame
stat_bar.tool_tip: KTris Drawn: (per frame) Computer-generated 3D objects are built out of triangles (the basic geometric shape). This is a count of the number of triangles, or 'tris', in each frame of the current scene.

stat_bar.name: ktrissec
stat_bar.label: KTris Drawn per Sec
stat_bar.tool_tip: KTris Drawn: (per second) Computer-generated 3D objects are built out of triangles (the basic geometric shape). This is a count of the number of triangles ('tris') drawn every second.

stat_bar.name: objs
stat_bar.label: Total Objects
stat_bar.tool_tip: Total Objs: The number of objects currently in view, which includes: Prims, Avatars, Terrain patches, Trees, Particle groups, and Water patches.

stat_bar.name: newobjs
stat_bar.label: New Objects
stat_bar.tool_tip: New Objs: The number of objects being downloaded per second.

stat_bar.name: numimagesstat
stat_bar.label: Texture Count
stat_bar.tool_tip: Count: The number of unique textures loaded by the viewer.

text.name: T_LR_Axis
text.tool_tip: Adjusts the sensitivity of the Left/Right movement. If you find it difficult to move with precision, use lower scale values.

text.name: T_UD_Axis
text.tool_tip: Adjusts the sensitivity of the Up/Down movement. If you find it difficult to move with precision, use lower scale values.

text.name: T_IO_Axis
text.tool_tip: Adjusts the sensitivity of the In/Out movement. If you find it difficult to move with precision, use lower scale values.

text.name: T_Tilt
text.tool_tip: Adjusts the sensitivity of the Pitch movement. If you find it difficult to move with precision, use lower scale values.

text.name: T_Spin
text.tool_tip: Adjusts the sensitivity of the Yaw movement. If you find it difficult to move with precision, use lower scale values.

text.name: T_Roll
text.tool_tip: Adjusts the sensitivity of the Roll movement. If you find it difficult to move with precision, use lower scale values.

text.name: T_Zoom_Speed
text.tool_tip: Adjusts the sensitivity of the Zoom speed. If you find it difficult to zoom with precision, use lower scale values.

text.name: T_Feathering
text.tool_tip: Setting the slider all the way to the right will make the camera very rigid, giving complete control to the joystick. Setting the slider all the way to the left will make the camera very fluid like the camera weighs a lot; good for fly-by shots, not good for framing.

spinner.label: Zoom Axis Mapping
spinner.name: JoystickAxis6
spinner.tool_tip: Controls which mouse axis the zooming function is mapped to (set to work with).

check_box.label: Enable 3D Mouse
check_box.tool_tip: This turns on the 3D Mouse.

check_box.name: CB_ZoomDirect
check_box.label: Enable Zoom Control (See Tool Tip!)
check_box.tool_tip: In order for the zooming control to work, you must set the 'Zoom Axis Mapping' above to '4'.

check_box.name: CB_AutoLeveling
check_box.label: Enable Auto Leveling (Prevents Camera Roll)
check_box.tool_tip: When enabled the camera will always remain level.

check_box.name: CB_Move_Avatar
check_box.label: Use the 3D Mouse to move the avatar
check_box.tool_tip: When enabled the mouse will move your avatar.

check_box.name: CB_Move_Objects
check_box.label: Use the 3D Mouse to move objects (building)
check_box.tool_tip: Uses the 3D mouse to move objects when building and editing.

check_box.label: Show the Current FOV of Viewer Screen
check_box.tool_tip: This will show you the vertical field of view for the camera. Within the viewer it is possible to change the lens length just like in real life. The smaller the FOV the longer the camera lens. A 50mm lens has a FOV of 27.0 degrees. To adjust the FOV use the zoom slider bar below. Please see: 'http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angle_of_view' for a table showing the relationship between FOV and Lens Focal Length (mm). TURN IT OFF BEFORE YOU TAKE SNAPSHOTS OR IT WILL BE IN THE PICTURE!
check_box.name: CAM_Show_FOV

text.name: T_Zoom2
text.tool_tip: In real world terms this is a Zoom feature. This will change the field of view in your viewer window. It is the same as hitting Ctrl + 0 or Ctrl+8. NOTE: This will not function if you have flycam enabled (3D SpaceNavigator).

text.name: T_Zoom_Speed2
text.tool_tip: Controls how fast/slow the camera will zoom in and out. Higher values produce slower and smoother zoom.

text.name: T_Camera_Lag
text.tool_tip: Amount camera lags behind avatar motion (0 = none, 30 = avatar velocity).

text.name: T_Camera_Offset
text.tool_tip: Controls how far the camera is offset/distance from the default point of view.

text.name: T_Cam_Smoothing
text.tool_tip: Controls how smoothly the camera starts and stops. Higher values produce smoother (and somewhat slower) movement.

text.name: T_Mouse_Sens
text.tool_tip: Controls responsiveness of mouse when in mouselook mode.

check_box.label: Display avatar & attachments in mouselook
check_box.tool_tip: Displays avatar and attachments below neck while in mouselook. Default is OFF.

check_box.label: Smooth Mouselook Movements
check_box.tool_tip: Smooths out motion of mouse when in mouselook mode.
check_box.name: MouseSmooth

check_box.label: Clicking your avatar keeps camera position
check_box.name: clickonavatarkeepscamera
check_box.tool_tip: Normally, clicking on your avatar resets the camera position. This option removes this behavior.

check_box.label: Reset camera position after teleport
check_box.name: FSResetCameraOnTP
check_box.tool_tip: Normally, the camera position gets reset when teleporting (within a region). This option prevents this behavior.

check_box.label: Disable minimum camera zoom distance
check_box.name: disableminzoomdist
check_box.tool_tip: Disable the constraint on the closest distance the camera is allowed to get to an object.

check_box.label: Allow the camera to move w/o constraints
check_box.name: ignorecameraconstraints
check_box.tool_tip: Ignores the 'push' the simulator applies to your camera to keep it out of objects. REQUIRES RESTART!

check_box.label: Reset camera position on avatar movement
check_box.name: resetcamerapositiononmovement
check_box.tool_tip: Resets the camera to its default position when you move the avatar
